clinical_study.brief_title: Trial to Reduce Sitting Time in Postmenopausal Latina Women at Increased Risk for Heart Disease
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Control Trial to Reduce Sitting Time in Postmenopausal Latina Women at Increased Risk for Heart Disease

brief_summary.textblock: Project 2 of the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) American Heart Association (AHA) Women's Health Program will assess 3-month changes in sitting time, standing time, physical activity and blood pressure in a randomized control trial. This 2-arm randomized controlled trial (RCT) will occur in the community with post menopausal Latina women (N=250) who spend at least 8 hrs/day sitting and have increased risk for cardiovascular disease through high BMI and borderline hypertension. Women will be identified through the San Ysidro Health Clinic and assessed at the South Bay Latino Research Center.

detailed_description.textblock:
Project 2 will address the following aims:
1. Investigate the 3 month effect of the intervention to impact the primary behavioral outcomes of sitting, standing and stepping time assessed objectively by a thigh worn inclinometer (ActivPAL) in Latinas at risk for heart disease.
2. Investigate the 3 month effect of the intervention to impact the secondary health outcomes of blood pressure, depressive symptoms, and anthropometrics.
3. Explore the psychosocial & environmental mediators & moderators of changes in sitting time.

primary_outcome.description: Change in daily time spent sitting, standing and stepping during waking hours as measured objectively by the ActivPAL

arm_group.description: The 'reduce sitting' intervention group will receive three in-person health education sessions followed by five counseling phone calls. Participants will wear a thigh worn inclinometer for the first 3 weeks of the intervention. At each in-person health education session participants will receive feedback from the ActivPAL showing periods throughout the day where participants have been sitting. In addition to the three initial in-person counseling sessions using the ActivPAL feedback, participants will receive phone calls from the health educator biweekly to help overcome barriers, to work on self-monitoring and planning skills, and to prepare relapse prevention. Tools to help prompt standing will also be provided.

Participants in the attention control condition will receive a healthy living educational intervention developed and tested by the investigators in previous studies. This group will receive an equal number of contacts as those in the intervention arms.

intervention.intervention_name: In-person counseling: Breaking up sitting time
intervention.description: Participants will receive 3 in-person health education sessions. At these sessions participants will receive feedback from the ActivPAL showing periods throughout the day where participants have been sitting. Participants will also develop action plans, check-in on goal setting, and use of tools at these sessions.

Participants will receive a healthy living educational intervention over the phone, developed and tested by the investigators in previous studies. Participants will not receive any information on diet, physical activity or sedentary behavior that may affect the outcomes.

Investigators will provide standing desks to participants who spend time sitting at a computer. Additional tools to help prompt standing are mechanical and electronic timers set to interrupt long periods of sitting and cues in the environment such as standing during commercial breaks and phone calls.

Control subjects will receive one in-person counseling session about healthy living. Participants will not receive any information on diet, physical activity or sedentary behavior that may affect the outcomes.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Female with no menstruation for at least 1 year, and 55 years of age or older
2. Self-identify as Hispanic ethnicity,
3. Able to read English or Spanish,
4. Able to walk or stand for short periods of time,
5. Have no medical conditions that would affect your ability to participate,
6. Have slightly high blood pressure (systolic blood pressure (SBP) between 120 and 139 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure (DBP) between 80 and 89 mmHg),
7. Have phone access (to receive counseling calls),
8. Have Body Mass Index in the range of 27-45 kg/m2,
9. Sit for more than 8 hours on most days and walk less than 8000 steps each day as measured by a small thigh worn device,
10. Are not participating in another related research study.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Unable to complete the Short Physical Performance Battery.
2. Mental states that would preclude complete understanding of the protocol and compliance.
3. Chronic illness that may be associated with weight change (HIV/AIDS, active cancer, or uncontrolled thyroid disease).
4. Body Mass Index <27.0 or >45.0kg/m2.
5. Arthritis or degenerative joint disease affecting knees if repeated sitting/standing interruptions might cause pain.
6. Type 1 diabetes mellitus
7. Hypertension (SBP ≥140 mmHg or DBP ≥90 mmHg).
8. Weight instability in past 3 months (no more than 5% up or down).
9. Participants <65 years of age with HbA1c ≥53 mmol/mol (7%) and participants ≥65 years of age with HbA1c ≥58mmol/mol (7.5%) will be excluded for uncontrolled diabetes.34,35
10. Use of insulin medications.
11. Use of any immunosuppressant or corticosteroid medication.
12. Use of medications that might cause weight change (e.g., second generation anti-psychotics).
13. ≤ 8hr average daily sitting time, as measured by ActivPAL.
14. ≥8000 steps/day average, as measured by ActivPAL
15. Participating in another clinical trial related to study outcomes (as determined by the PI).
16. Smoking cigarettes or anything, and other use of tobacco products.
17. Chronic Venous Insufficiency resulting in discomfort when standing for 5 minutes.
